question_text: What is true about Iterative Development?
option: Development is organized into a series of "mini-projects".
The output of an iteration is an experimental prototype(leads to rapid feedback from users).
One of the benefits of Iterative Development is early feedback.
One of the benefits of Iterative Development is late mitigationof high risks.
Each iteration includes only one discipline (i.e. RequirementsAnalysis, Design, Implementation, or Testing).

question_text: What is true about iterations?
option: The UP recommends an iteration length between two and six weeks.
The UP recommends an iteration length between six and twelve months.
If it seems that it will be difficult to meet the deadline, the recommendedresponse is to remove tasks from the iteration.
If it seems that it will be difficult to meet the deadline, the recommendedresponse is to slip the completion date.

question_text: What is true about UP Phases?
option: Inception is not a requirements phase.
Elaboration is not a design phase.

question_text: What is true about Use Cases?
option: Requirements are primarily recorded in Use Cases.
Requirements are primarily recorded in Function Lists, rather thanin Use Cases.
The work of an iteration is defined by choosing some Use Case scenarios, or entire Use Cases.
The work of an iteration is defined by choosing some feature fromFeature List, rather than by choosing some Use Case scenarios, orentire Use Cases.

question_text: By the end of Elaboration phase ...
option: there is basis for estimation through to the end of the project.
non-functional requirements (in the Supplementary Specification)are written.

question_text: Using the "Post News" Use Case main success scenario, determine the system operations and return values for System Sequence Diagram (SSD).Use Case: Post NewsPrimary Actor: ClientMain success scenario: A writer client logs on to the server in order to start a posting session and may post a number of news items. Each news item receives an individual confirmation and at the end of posting, the system issues a general confirmation. News items are stored in a database.
You are creating "NewsService" system - a multiuser system which includes many screens and many workflows. What is the best practice to clarify the vision of functional requirements?
option: Spend more time in Inception Phase.
Add more details in Supplementary Specification.
Prepare Use Cases in fully dressed format.

A class in Domain Package uses the services of a classin Database Package

question_text: GUI Package depends on Database Package.

option: Classes in the same inheritance hierarchy.
Classes participate the same Use Case.
Classes created by the same developer.
Classes created by the same team.

option: Client and Server reside on different computers.
Client and Server reside on the same computer.

Given the "Post News" Use Case, is there anything wrong with the following partial domain model?Use Case: Post NewsPrimary Actor: ClientPreconditions: 1. Client is authenticated. (Authentication)2. Server has not reached its maximum allowable number of clients logged in. (Authentication)3. No other client is currently reading news. (Synchronization)4. No other client is currently posting news. (Synchronization)5. No other client is currently waiting to post news. (Scheduling)Main success scenario: A writer client logs on to the server in order to start a posting session and may post a number of news items. Each news item receives an individual confirmation and at the end of posting, the system issues a general confirmation. News items are stored in a database.
option: Synchronization, Scheduling, Authentication must be attributes of NewsServer class.
Client conceptual class must not to be shown,because it is an external actor (human).
The domain model does not use the vocabulary of thedomain when naming conceptual classes.

question_text: During one of requirements workshops the "NewsService" stakeholder said that she needsnews items be categorized in the system (e.g. Politics, World News , Local News). The categories may be hierarchical (e.g. Local News / Career / Job).How can this requirements be satisfied?
option: Add new Category conceptual class and draw association with NewsItem class.
Add new category attribute to NewsItem class.
Do not do anything. Add category name in thebody of each news text.
Add new category attribute to NewsDatabase class.

question_text: "A client logs on to the server in order to start a session and may post or read news. When the user does not submit a request for the specified length of time, the server invalidates the session." Which Class Diagram shows the best design?

Given the "Post News" Use Case, is there anything wrong with the following partial domain model?Use Case: Post NewsPrimary Actor: ClientPreconditions: 1. Client is authenticated. (Authentication)2. Server has not reached its maximum allowable number of clients logged in. (Authentication)3. No other client is currently reading news. (Synchronization)4. No other client is currently posting news. (Synchronization)5. No other client is currently waiting to post news. (Scheduling)Main success scenario: A writer client logs on to the server in order to start a posting session and may post a number of news items. Each news item receives an individual confirmation and at the end of posting, the system issues a general confirmation. News items are stored in a database.
option: Client and NewsServer classes may not havemultiple associations.

question_text: Give correct names to classes' relationships.

The "NewsService" provides registered Users notification when new NewsItems are posted.The Timer thread polls queue which contains recently posted items and sends notifications.Each registered User must receive only one notification per NewsItem. Thus, the system should store information about notification status (sent/not sent).What class will be responsible for storing the status of notification?
Is there anything wrong with the Session class?
option: Session class is not well encapsulated.
Session class does not support low dependency.
Session class has too many responsibilities, which lowers its cohesion.

question_text: In the "NewsService" system there are multiple third-party databases frameworksthat must be supported. The system needs to be able to integrate with different ones. Each database framework facade has a different interface, and so there is similar but varying behavior to adapt to each of these external fixed interfaces or APIs.Which of the following are the best approaches to satisfy this requirement?
option: Test for the type of database framework facade and use conditional logic to perform varying   alternatives based on type.
Assign responsibility for the behavior to the types for which the behavior varies.
Identify points of predicted variation or instability; assign responsibilities to create a stable interface around them.
Define each algorithm in a separate class, with a common interface.
